awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Spatial and temporal variability of surface albedo and light absorbing chemical species in Greenland.
awd_abstract_narration: The collaborative team will take advantage of the currently funded Greenland Inland Traverse (GrIT) traveling between Thule and Summit Greenland to access a spatially diverse area of the GIS in order to better understand albedo variability and the snow properties that influence albedo. The GrIT route offers a unique opportunity to study a wide range of snow accumulation zones (i.e. the ablation zone, soaked snow zone, the percolation zone and the dry snow zone) across Greenland, which are expected to have a broad range of albedo values as well as significant variability in snow physical properties and concentrations of light absorbing compounds (i.e. dust, elemental carbon, and brown carbon). The project's field component will take place over two seasons during the spring of 2013 and 2014. The approach will include stopping along the traverse to collect coincident daily measurements of snow spectral albedo, snow physical properties (i.e. specific surface area, density), surface snow light absorption properties (i.e. wavelength dependent absorption of water soluble compounds and particulates), and the concentrations of trace elements, organic, and elemental carbon. Additionally, the temporal evolution of spectral albedo will be monitored continuously during the sunlit months using autonomous stations deployed along the traverse route to track seasonal variations of snow albedo and to help attribute these variations to the physical and chemical composition of the snow.  The results of this project will yield a unique data set characterizing the temporal and spatial variability of surface albedo as well as the physical and chemical properties of Greenland snow, which are broadly useful to both modeling, ice mass balance, and remote sensing communities. Conference presentations, rapid publication of results, and most importantly close collaboration with modelers, (i.e. through work with the CESM PCWG) will ensure that this knowledge used to improve process parameterizations in predictive global climate models.  The team will also build on international collaborations begun in the Dartmouth IGERT program, including a week-long ambassadorship to Nuuk by co-PI Polashenski including lectures at the college and Katuuaq cultural center.  Graduate, undergraduate, and high school student training will also be included in the project.

por.por_cntn:
The Sunlight Absorption across the Greenland Ice Sheet Experiment (SAGE) was funded under the NSF project “Collaborative research: Spatial and temporal variability of surface albedo and light absorbing chemical species in Greenland (Award# 1546002).”  The goal of this work is to measure the spatial and temporal variability of the surface spectral albedo (how much snow reflects incident light of different “color”) across the Greenland Ice Sheet (GIS) and to quantify and partition the roles different physical processes play in contributing to that variability. Specifically, we are investigating the impact on surface snow albedo from snow grain size and microstructure, the deposition of black carbon, dust and other particulate matter, and wetness on the surface (caused by melting).

The SAGE project combined an extensive field, lab and modeling effort.  Laboratory analyses of snow samples from 67 sites collected as part of a two-year field effort represent the largest black carbon/dust/snow physical property data set collected to date, providing an unprecedented resource to validate signals from satellite-based instruments, including NASA’s MODIS instrument in particular.  Interpretation of the spatially distributed observations demonstrated that an apparent decline in albedo across the dry snow zone of the ice sheet from MODIS returns was not due to black carbon from biomass burning events or dust, as had been previously suggested, but was in fact an artifact of a degrading sensor.  Enhanced levels of BC from wildfires in summer 2012 were only found in a few pits, all near the summit of the ice sheet, calling into question published assertions that widespread darkening by soot from fires contributed to record melt over nearly the entire ice sheet that summer.

Black carbon concentrations from the pits and surface snow sampled in 2013 and 2014 indicate a complex depositional pattern, and present the most comprehensive and widely sampled study of coupled snow chemistry and physical properties including black carbon measurements in Greenland to date.  We have found that light absorbing aerosols over Greenland may be playing an important role, if relatively minor compared to other factors, in the radiation balance of the ice sheet, particularly in defining the spatial variability in snow albedo. One interesting finding is that snow surface microstructure and chemistry can vary over scales of 1-10 m, with variations at these smaller scales on the order of variations occurring over several 10’s of km. The small scale variability must be linked to depositional and post-depositional processes rather than atmospheric transport. 

Field measurements of 10m depth temperatures across the northern Greenland Ice Sheet from May 2013 compared to measurements by Benson from 1952-1955 at the same locations, show long term trends. We found substantial warming (up to +5.7C) at 1400-2500 m elevations and little temperature change at high elevations (>2500 m). Latent heat transport into the snowpack due to meltwater percolation drives the observed warming. Modeling shows that heat is stored at depth for several years and energy delivered from consecutive melt events accumulates. The observed warming is likely not yet in equilibrium with recent melt production rates, but captures the steady upward climb of the zone around the interior ice sheet where enough melting occurs in the summer to produce runoff.  

The work involved training opportunities for four graduate students and several undergraduate students from Georgia Tech and Dartmouth College.  For the students who participated in the Greenland field campaign, this was their first research trip in Greenland, and the first expedition-type research experience.  In addition, undergraduate students from Dartmouth College, the University of Vermont, and high school students assisted with lab measurements and data analysis. The students have learned about the science background of the research work in addition to receiving training in data analysis techniques, laboratory techniques and basic physical modeling. One high school student even developed his own surface energy balance model, is a coauthor on two published journal articles, and presented a poster at the 2014 Fall AGU meeting.

We have published three journal articles and have two other manuscripts in progress related to aerosols and absorption of solar energy to be submitted in the near future in addition to several presentations made at major national and international conferences about the work.  A blog of the field experiment has been widely read and has been archived at coldregionsscience.wordpress.com.  In addition, several media stories about the work were published including a PBS NOVANEXT story “Greenland’s Disappearing Glaciers—A Tale of Fire and Ice” (19 May 2014), Vermont Public Radio, New Hampshire Public Radio, and local newspapers features.  Outreach events including teacher training programs, summer STEM camps for local 8th grade students, and numerous other presentations made to general audiences have included over 1300 people over the course of the project.   

Data from the project can be found at:

Firn Temperatures from NW Greenland-doi:10.18739/A2NQ09

Snow/Firn Chemistry from NW Greenland-doi:10.18739/A2SH3M
